question: Which of these characterizes the vector $\mathbf{x} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 0 & 0 \end{bmatrix}^T$

answers.feedback: Incorrect. A zero vector would have all elements equal to 0, but this vector has one element equal to 1.
Incorrect. A ones vector would have all elements equal to 1, but this vector has two elements equal to 0.
Correct! This is a standard unit vector (specifically e₁) because it has a 1 in the first position and 0s elsewhere.
Incorrect -- try again.

question: Which of these characterizes the vector $\mathbf{x} = \begin{bmatrix} 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 \end{bmatrix}^T$?

answers.feedback: Correct! This is a zero vector because all of its elements are 0.
Incorrect. A ones vector would have all elements equal to 1, but this vector has all elements equal to 0.
Incorrect. A standard unit vector has a single 1 in one position and 0s elsewhere, but this vector has all 0s.
Incorrect -- try again.

question: Which of these characterizes the vector $\mathbf{x} = \begin{bmatrix} 0 & 1 & 0 & 0 \end{bmatrix}^T$?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. A zero vector would have all elements equal to 0, but this vector has one element equal to 1.
Incorrect. A ones vector would have all elements equal to 1, but this vector has three elements equal to 0.
Correct! This is a standard unit vector (specifically e₂) because it has a 1 in the second position and 0s elsewhere.
Incorrect -- try again.

question: Which of these characterizes the vector $\mathbf{x} = \begin{bmatrix} \sqrt{2}/2 & \sqrt{2}/2 \end{bmatrix}^T$?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. A zero vector would have all elements equal to 0.
Incorrect. A ones vector would have all elements equal to 1.
Incorrect. A standard unit vector has a single 1 in one position and 0s elsewhere.
Correct! (General unit vectors have not been covered at this point in the text, but this is a unit vector, but not a standard unit vector.)

question: Which of these characterizes the vector $\mathbf{x} = \begin{bmatrix} 1/2 & 1/2 \end{bmatrix}^T$?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. A zero vector would have all elements equal to 0, but this vector has non-zero elements.
Incorrect. A ones vector would have all elements equal to 1, but this vector has all elements equal to 1/2.
Incorrect. A standard unit vector has a single 1 in one position and 0s elsewhere, but this vector has 1/2 in both positions.
Correct!

question: Which of these characterizes the vector $\mathbf{x} = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 & 1 \end{bmatrix}^T$?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. A zero vector would have all elements equal to 0, but this vector has all elements equal to 1.
Correct! This is a ones vector because all of its elements are 1.
Incorrect. A standard unit vector has a single 1 in one position and 0s elsewhere, but this vector has 1s in all positions.
Incorrect -- try again.

question: Which of these characterizes the vector $\mathbf{x} = \begin{bmatrix} 0 & 0 & 1/2 \end{bmatrix}^T$?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. A zero vector would have all elements equal to 0, but this vector has one element equal to 1/2.
Incorrect. A ones vector would have all elements equal to 1, but this vector has two elements equal to 0 and one element equal to 1/2.
Incorrect. A standard unit vector has a single 1 in one position and 0s elsewhere, but this vector has 1/2 in the third position.
Correct!
